por.por_cntn:
The project belongs to the general area of dynamical systems which qualitatively studies evolution of a system as time goes by. More specifically the PI was working on partially hyperbolic dynamical systems which is one class of dynamical systems displaying strong chaotic behavior. Chaotic dynamics is abundant in real life and appears throughout sciences and engineering. It appears in simple mechanisms such as double pendulum as well as in complicated nature phenomena such as convection currents in the atmosphere and liquids. The study of such naturally occurring examples is extremely challenging and we are very far from understanding them well. Partial hyperbolicity provides a simplified setting in which progress can be made. 

The project was largely focused on the interaction of partial hyperbolicity and topology of the topology of the underlying space. Other more analytic problems were also studied. The following are some notable results of the project.

In collaboration with F.T. Farrell the PI initiated the study of fiberwise Anosov bundles by establishing some rigidity results. This already generated some interest geometry community and in dynamics community. By using the idea of fiberwise Anosov diffeomorphisms the PI, jointly with F. Rodriguez Hertz and P. Ontaneda, constructed first examples of partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms on simply connected manifolds. Further, the PI developed certain surgical constructions to further enlarge the class of fiberwise Anosov partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms.

In collaboration with C. Bonatti, R. Potrie and A. Hammerlindl many new 3-demenional partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms were constructed settling a well-known question in the field (Pujals Conjecture).


The PI widely disseminated the research results by participating in conferences and giving seminar talks. In 2016 the PI gave a 16 lecture advanced mini-course at YMSC, Tsinghua University. The PI was running an after school math circle in Vestal Middle School, Vestal NY in 2015-17. Jointly with A.N. Kolmogorov (Binghamton University, Physics) the PI introduced an undergraduate student I. Maimon into some research level questions in dynamics. This resulted in a joint paper.
